name: nytimes
text:
The monolith that mysteriously appeared in the Utah desert has disappeared.

Here's what happened to it. https://t.co/6WREg8pOSp

name: nytimes
text:
The pop-up metal sculpture became the focus of international attention after it was spotted in the Utah desert on Nov. 18. It was dismantled just 10 days later.

Where it came from — and where it went — remains a mystery. https://t.co/6WREg8pOSp https://t.co/9GqHoagJL9

name: nytimes
text:
Government officials continued to insist on Monday that they had no information about either the installation or removal — and possible theft — of the monolith.

So it was left to an adventure photographer, Ross Bernards, to disclose evidence on Instagram. https://t.co/6WREg8pOSp

name: nytimes
text: Bernards was visiting the monolith on Friday night when, he said, four men arrived as if out of nowhere to take down the sculpture. It popped out and landed on the ground with a bang, he said. Then the men broke it apart, ferrying it off in a wheelbarrow. https://t.co/6WREg8pOSp https://t.co/grDyEzjszY

name: nytimes
text: The photos Bernards shared are the only known images of the culprits who removed it. But it’s still not clear who installed it. "This is why you don’t leave trash in the desert,” one of them said, according to Bernards. https://t.co/6WREg8pOSp

name: nytimes
text: The monolith’s origins are still unknown. The David Zwirner gallery asserted that it’s the work of the late Minimalist sculptor John McCracken. But if that’s the case, he didn’t tell his dealer or friends. https://t.co/RaDvOkNXPu
